AERN (Approximating Exact Real Numbers) | Home

A Haskell library for interval and exact real computation, featuring a polynomial interval arithmetic.

Examples

Compute (tight) interval bounds and function enclosures

The logistic map is defined by the simple recurrence formula \[ x_{n+1} = rx_n(1-x_n) \] For almost all \(r\in[3.567,4]\) this system is chaotic.

A direct encoding in AERN with arbitrary precision support in the style of iRRAM computes tight interval enclosures for \(x_n\). For example, with \(r=3.75\) and \(x_0=0.5\), it computes:

\(n\) computation time computed enclosure of \(x_n\)
\(100\) 0.02s \(3.8545043842252...\pm 10^{-160}\)
\(1000\) 0.5s \(6.9714851192442...\pm 10^{-160}\)
\(10000\) 72s \(6.7381614749956...\pm 10^{-160}\)

Enclose solutions of differential equations

[under construction]

Enclose solutions of hybrid systems

[under construction]

Prove or disprove numerical theorems

[under construction]

Origin

  • AERN has been under development since 2005, mainly at Aston University
  • AERN was initially inspired by the C++ library iRRAM
  • The project has been sponsored by EPSRC and Altran Praxis
